capability.name: Food Safety & Traceability
capability.description: Farm-to-fork traceability, HACCP plan management, temperature monitoring, allergen control, supplier food safety audits, and rapid recall capabilities

functions.name: Lot & Batch Traceability (Farm-to-Fork)
functions.description: Complete supply chain visibility from farm/supplier through production to customer with 1-step-up/1-step-back tracking for rapid trace-back and trace-forward

traditional.approach: Lot traceability is maintained through manual record-keeping at each supply chain stage. Suppliers provide lot numbers on shipping documents and certificates. Production teams record ingredient lot numbers and finished goods batch codes on paper batch records. Distribution centers track inventory by lot in WMS systems. Customer shipments are documented with lot codes on invoices. During recalls or quality investigations, tracing requires manual queries across multiple disconnected systems, contacting suppliers by phone/email, and reviewing paper records. Complete trace-back or trace-forward typically takes 8-24 hours or longer.
limitations: Manual record-keeping at each stage creates gaps and delays in traceability
Disconnected systems prevent rapid end-to-end tracing during food safety events
Trace-back from customer to farm takes 8-24 hours or longer, allowing continued distribution of unsafe product
Paper records are incomplete, illegible, or lost, compromising traceability
Inability to quickly identify affected customers during recalls increases consumer risk

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive farm-to-fork traceability through integrated supply chain systems. Lot capture agents automatically record supplier lot numbers from receiving documents (ASN, BOL, COA) and link to purchase orders. Production agents capture ingredient lot consumption and finished goods batch relationships during manufacturing with real-time validation of data completeness. Distribution agents track lot movement through warehouses and shipments to customers with automated lot-to-customer linking. Trace agents provide 15-minute rapid trace-back (customer → ingredients → supplier farms) and trace-forward (supplier lot → finished goods → customers) through automated queries across integrated systems. Visualization agents display supply chain maps showing all affected products and locations.

orchestrator.description: Coordinates lot data capture, production batch recording, distribution tracking, rapid trace-back/forward, and supply chain visualization

benefits: Trace-back time reduces from 8-24 hours to 15 minutes meeting FDA FSMA requirements
Complete supply chain visibility enables precise recalls reducing product destruction and customer impact
Real-time validation during production ensures traceability data completeness vs. discovering gaps during recalls
Automated trace-forward identifies all affected customers in minutes enabling rapid notification
Supply chain visualization supports risk assessment and recall scope decisions

functions.name: Food Safety Plan Management (HACCP)
functions.description: HACCP plan development, critical control point monitoring, automated deviation alerts, corrective action management, and verification activities

traditional.approach: HACCP plans are developed manually by food safety teams documenting critical control points (CCPs), critical limits, monitoring procedures, and corrective actions in Word documents. CCP monitoring is recorded on paper logs by production operators who manually check temperatures, pH, water activity, or other parameters at scheduled intervals. Deviations from critical limits require manual notification to supervisors and quality managers. Corrective action documentation is completed on paper forms after the fact. HACCP verification activities (calibration checks, record review, validation) are scheduled manually and tracked in spreadsheets. Annual HACCP plan reviews are labor-intensive document updates.
limitations: Paper-based CCP monitoring creates data entry delays and transcription errors
Deviation detection relies on operator vigilance with delayed escalation to management
Corrective action documentation is often incomplete or delayed, creating compliance gaps
Manual verification tracking leads to missed calibrations and review deadlines
Difficult to analyze CCP trends to identify process improvement opportunities

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive HACCP program management. Plan management agents maintain digital HACCP plans with automated versioning, change tracking, and approval workflows. Monitoring agents integrate with sensors and production equipment to capture CCP data in real-time (temperature, pH, water activity, metal detection) with automated comparison to critical limits. Deviation agents immediately detect excursions, send multi-level alerts (operator, supervisor, quality manager), and initiate corrective action workflows. Corrective action agents guide operators through standardized responses, document actions taken, and verify effectiveness. Verification agents automate scheduling of calibrations, record reviews, and validation studies with deadline tracking and completion verification.

functions.name: Temperature Monitoring & Alerts
functions.description: Continuous temperature monitoring using IoT sensors, real-time out-of-range alerts, automated compliance reporting, and cold chain integrity verification

traditional.approach: Temperature monitoring relies on manual checks by warehouse and production staff who walk through facilities recording temperatures from thermometers on paper logs 2-3 times per shift. Refrigerated trucks and shipping containers use single-use temperature data loggers that are read upon arrival. Cold chain deviations are discovered after the fact when reviewing logs or data loggers, often hours or days after temperature excursions. Manual temperature logs are compiled monthly for regulatory compliance reporting. No real-time visibility into temperature conditions across distributed supply chain locations. Alarm systems in some facilities alert locally but not to centralized monitoring.
limitations: Manual temperature checks 2-3 times per shift miss deviations occurring between readings
Temperature excursions discovered hours/days later when product safety may be compromised
Paper logs are incomplete, illegible, or falsified, creating compliance and safety risks
Single-use data loggers provide historical data but no real-time intervention capability
No aggregated view of cold chain integrity across supply chain

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive temperature monitoring across the cold chain. IoT sensor agents continuously measure temperatures in warehouses, production areas, coolers, freezers, refrigerated trucks, and shipping containers, transmitting data every 1-5 minutes. Alert agents immediately detect out-of-range conditions and send multi-level notifications (facility operators, managers, quality teams) via SMS, email, and mobile apps. Response agents guide operators through investigation and corrective action procedures with documentation. Compliance agents automatically generate regulatory temperature reports with exception summaries. Analytics agents identify patterns in temperature deviations to recommend equipment maintenance, loading procedure changes, or route optimization.

functions.name: Allergen Management & Labeling
functions.description: Allergen tracking through supply chain, cross-contamination prevention procedures, label accuracy verification, and allergen cleaning validation

traditional.approach: Allergen management relies on manual documentation at each supply chain stage. Suppliers provide allergen declarations on specifications and certificates. Production schedules are manually sequenced to minimize changeovers between allergen and allergen-free products. Allergen cleaning procedures are documented on paper with manual verification through visual inspection and swabbing. Label allergen declarations are checked manually by comparing ingredient lists to allergen databases. Production line changeovers involve manual verification that cleaning procedures were completed. No systematic tracking of allergen cross-contamination risks or near-misses across facilities.
limitations: Manual allergen declarations from suppliers are inconsistent and may be incomplete
Production scheduling does not systematically optimize to reduce allergen changeovers
Visual inspection of allergen cleaning is subjective and unreliable
Label allergen errors discovered after printing cause costly recalls and consumer harm
Limited visibility into cross-contamination risk patterns across product families and facilities

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive allergen management. Allergen data agents collect and validate supplier allergen declarations ensuring completeness and consistency across ingredients. Formulation agents track allergens through recipes and automatically update when ingredients change. Scheduling agents optimize production sequences to minimize allergen changeovers while balancing throughput. Cleaning validation agents manage allergen cleaning procedures with digital checklists, photo documentation, and environmental monitoring result tracking. Label verification agents automatically validate allergen declarations on labels against formulations, flagging errors before printing. Risk analytics agents identify cross-contamination patterns and near-misses to improve controls.

functions.name: Supplier Food Safety Audits
functions.description: Risk-based supplier audit scheduling, mobile audit execution, finding management with corrective actions, and supplier certification tracking

traditional.approach: Supplier food safety audits are scheduled annually or during new supplier qualification using manual calendars. Audit teams travel to supplier facilities with paper checklists based on GFSI standards (SQF, BRC, FSSC 22000) or custom protocols. Auditors manually document observations, take photos with cameras, and compile findings in Word reports after returning from site visits (1-2 weeks delay). Audit findings are shared with suppliers via email with requests for corrective action plans. Corrective action tracking happens in spreadsheets with manual follow-up. Third-party certifications (SQF, BRC) are tracked in spreadsheets with manual renewal monitoring.
limitations: Annual audit schedules miss food safety risks that emerge between scheduled audits
Paper-based execution delays audit reports by 1-2 weeks, slowing corrective action
Manual corrective action tracking has low completion rates (60-70%)
Third-party certification lapses discovered late cause supplier disruptions
Difficult to compare audit results across suppliers or identify systemic issues

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive supplier food safety audit programs. Risk scoring agents prioritize audits based on supplier performance (quality, delivery, compliance history), commodity risk, and previous audit findings. Scheduling agents manage audit calendars, coordinate resources, and send supplier notifications. Mobile audit agents provide auditors with tablet apps featuring digital GFSI checklists, integrated photo/video capture, offline capability, and real-time finding documentation. Report generation agents automatically compile findings into standardized reports immediately after audits with severity ratings and recommendations. CAPA management agents track supplier corrective action plans, monitor deadlines, and verify effectiveness through follow-up data. Certification agents monitor third-party certifications and alert when renewals are needed.

functions.name: Rapid Recall & Trace-Back
functions.description: 15-minute trace capability from customer to supplier, automated customer notification workflows, effectiveness verification, and regulatory compliance

traditional.approach: Product recalls for food safety require manual trace-back investigations across disconnected systems. Quality teams manually query ERP for affected lot numbers, search production batch records (often paper) to identify ingredients, contact suppliers by phone/email for farm or source information, and compile customer distribution data from multiple systems. Complete trace-back takes 8-24 hours or longer. Customer notifications are prepared manually and sent via phone, email, or postal mail. Effectiveness tracking relies on manual logging of customer responses and product returns. Regulatory filings (FDA, USDA) are prepared manually under time pressure.
limitations: Manual trace-back takes 8-24 hours while contaminated product remains in distribution
Incomplete traceability may require overly broad recalls affecting entire product categories
Customer notification delays increase consumer risk and regulatory non-compliance
Manual effectiveness tracking provides limited visibility into recall progress
High stress and error risk during manual food safety crisis response

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates rapid recall execution meeting FDA FSMA's 15-minute trace-back requirement. Trace-back agents immediately query integrated traceability systems to map customer complaints or positive test results backward through finished goods lots, production batches, ingredient lots, and supplier sources in under 15 minutes. Impact assessment agents determine full recall scope (products, lot codes, customers, geography) and calculate consumer exposure. Customer notification agents automatically generate and distribute recall alerts via multi-channel (email, SMS, portal, phone) with delivery tracking and response monitoring. Regulatory filing agents prepare FDA/USDA required documents using templates and submit electronically. Effectiveness agents track recall progress (customer acknowledgments, product returns, market withdrawal) in real-time dashboards. Post-recall analytics agents conduct root cause analysis and recommend preventive actions.
